chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of people with suspected uveitis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage someone with suspected uveitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer people with severe eye pain and a significant reduction in vision immediately for same-day assessment by an ophthalmologist. 
  • Refer people with suspected uveitis (new presentations, and recurrent) for assessment within 24 hours by an ophthalmologist. 
    • Urgent referral is required to confirm the diagnosis with a slit lamp examination with dilated pupils and measurement of intraocular pressure.
  • Uveitis should be managed by an ophthalmologist; secondary care treatment will depend on the underlying cause of the uveitis.
  • Do not initiate treatment for uveitis in primary care, unless asked to do so by an ophthalmologist.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Secondary care treatments
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Treatment of uveitis depends on the cause, location and severity of disease, and is aimed at controlling ocular disease and the underlying systemic condition (if present).  
  • Non-infectious uveitis
    • Corticosteroids are used to reduce inflammation and prevent adhesions in the eye. They may be given topically, orally, intravenously, intramuscularly, or by periocular or intraocular injection or implant. Corticosteroids are tapered slowly (over weeks) because withdrawing them too quickly may lead to rebound inflammation.
      • Corticosteroids achieve immediate control of inflammation rapidly and effectively, but long-term use is associated with numerous adverse effects. 
    • A cycloplegic-mydriatic drug (for example cyclopentolate 1% or atropine 1%) may also be given to paralyse the ciliary body. This relieves pain and prevents adhesions between the iris and lens.
    • People with severe or chronic uveitis may also be given systemic immunosuppressive drugs (for example, methotrexate or mycophenolate), tumour necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors (for example, adalimumab), laser phototherapy, cryotherapy, or have the vitreous removed surgically (vitrectomy).
  • Infectious uveitis
    • Infectious uveitis (bacterial, viral, fungal, or parasitic) is treated with an appropriate antimicrobial drug as well as corticosteroids and cycloplegics.

[Gupta, 2006; Guly, 2010; Yanoff, 2013; BMJ, 2018; MSD, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the College of Optometrists guidelines Uveitis (anterior) and Urgency of referrals [The College of Optometrists, 2019b], expert opinion in narrative reviews Investigation and management of uveitis [Guly, 2010], Evaluation of the painful eye [Pflipsen, 2016], Assessing the painful, uninflamed eye in primary care [Kuffova, 2015], Chronic non-infectious uveitis in the elderly: epidemiology, pathophysiology and management [Gupta, 2006], Diagnosis and treatment of anterior uveitis: optometric management [Harthan, 2016], and a medical textbook Ophthalmology [Yanoff, 2013]. 

Referral
  • The recommendations regarding referral are largely based on expert opinion in a narrative review [Guly, 2010], and a medical textbook Ophthalmology [Yanoff, 2013].
    • Uveitis cannot be diagnosed without slit-lamp examination which may show inflammatory cells that may aggregate to form 'snowballs'.
    • Uveitis usually resolves quickly with treatment; however, if it is not treated or is inadequately treated, it may result in profound and irreversible vision loss [Gupta, 2006; MSD, 2019]. 
  • People with eye pain in an uninflamed eye should be referred to secondary care [Kuffova, 2015]: 
    • Immediately (within hours)—if there is evidence of acute onset sight loss (more than two lines on Snellen chart), or suspicion of giant cell arteritis, or raised intracranial pressure.
    • Soon (within days)— if there is a perceived risk of sight loss based on the suspected diagnosis (such as chronic glaucoma or uveitis).
  • Eye pain with vision loss requires immediate ophthalmology referral [Pflipsen, 2016].  
  • Emergency referral (same day) to an ophthalmologist (with no intervention) is required for people with a significant reduction in vision, severe pain, or significantly raised intraocular pressure [The College of Optometrists, 2019a]. 
  • Emergency referral (within 24 hours) is required for people with uveitis [The College of Optometrists, 2019b]. 
Treatment
  • CKS recommends that people with suspected uveitis in primary care should be referred without treatment because:
    • The diagnosis must be confirmed by slit-lamp examination (not normally readily available in primary care).
    • Viral infections are the most common infectious underlying cause of anterior uveitis [Harthan, 2016]. 
    • If the person has herpes simplex virus infection, corticosteroids can transform a simple herpetic dendritic ulcer into an extensive amoeboid ulcer involving all layers of the cornea, with resultant corneal scarring and visual impairment [Frith et al, 2001].
    • Topical steroids should be used with care in eyes with herpes simplex uveitis because of the risk of exacerbation of corneal epithelial disease [Guly, 2010].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I follow-up someone diagnosed with uveitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Secondary care follow-up of uveitis includes monitoring for:
    • Treatment efficacy — if the person responds well to treatment the dose of corticosteroid may be reduced, then tapered over 6 weeks. 
    • Adverse effects, for example: 
      • Measuring intraocular pressure to assess for glaucoma as a result of corticosteroid use. 
      • Full blood count to check for neutropenia caused by immunosuppressants. 
    • Uveitis complications — for example, deterioration in vision.
  • Primary healthcare professionals may be asked to monitor:
    • For adverse effects of long-term oral corticosteroids (continuous or repeated courses).
      • For more information see the CKS topic Corticosteroids - oral.
    • The use of disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) or immunosuppressants, depending on locally-agreed shared care guidelines. For more information, see the CKS topic on DMARDs.
    • That people receiving repeat prescriptions of topical corticosteroids are under the care of an ophthalmologist (to monitor for corticosteroid-induced glaucoma).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Medical Journal (BMJ) Best Practice guide Uveitis [BMJ, 2018], the College of Optometrists guideline Uveitis (anterior) [The College of Optometrists, 2019b], expert opinion in narrative reviews Investigation and management of uveitis [Guly, 2010], and the British National Formulary [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019].
